title: Great Discoveries in Life Sciences
requirements: Not for Majors in Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences, BMEG Major & NSCI Major in YBSC, YBTC, YENS & YFNC and student taken BCHE2030,3030, 3080, BIOL2120,BMEG2000,2010 or LSCI1002;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course aims at deciphering how the discoveries by the work of some famous scientists in the field of life sciences has affected our daily life and our society. The course first provides students with the general knowledge of some basic processes in life, followed by how this knowledge has helped us to cope with the natural adversities such as diseases. The improvements of our quality of life by the biotechnological advances and how the development in life sciences has revolutionized our lives in life sciences will also be discussed. Finally, how the development in life sciences has brought revolutionizing impacts on our lives, civilization, and modernization will be presented. Through a series of learning activities, students are encouraged to comprehend and to connect the discoveries in life sciences to daily scenarios. This course is particularly suitable for students who are not life-science or medicine majors and who want to understand more on how discoveries in life sciences have transformed the way we think and live throughout the centuries.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:  recognize how life sciences can benefit our daily life  comprehend basic knowledge in life sciences  analyze and comment on the issues related to life sciences, for example, test tube babies and cloning in life sciences  develop practical skills in communication and critical thinking through different types of learning activities  gain learning methodologies that promote life-long learning in life science subjects
syllabus: This course focuses on how the discoveries by some famous scientists in life sciences, including many Nobel laureates, have influenced our daily life. The course first introduces the major breakthroughs in the life sciences which facilitate the understanding of the basic processes in life, followed by illustration of how these discoveries can prepare humans to fight off the natural adversities. Finally, the course covers the several major technological advances in life sciences and how they have contributed to human civilization and modernization.   Theme 1: Basic knowledge in Life Sciences This theme provides students with the basic knowledge in life sciences that prepares them for Theme 2 and Theme 3.  How does life evolve? – The theory of natural selection  How are genetic materials passed on through generations? – DNA and genes  Why are genetic materials important for life? – The translation of genetic materials to functional proteins   Theme 2: Life Science Discoveries to Benefit Health  This theme illustrates how the discoveries in life sciences have improved human health.  What is infection? – The story of microbes  How do humans battle infection? - The concept of infection and immunity  What is cancer? – Cancer-causing viruses and genes vs. tumour-suppressor genes   Theme 3: Life Science Discoveries and Technological Advances  This theme focuses on the remarkable technological advances that improve the living standard of humans.  How did modern biotechnology arise? – Advances in genetic engineering  How does biotechnology benefit humans? - Infertility problems and organ failure

title: Nutrition and Healthy Living
requirements: Not for Majors in Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences, BMEG Majors and Natural Sciences Majors in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC concentrations.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course aims at providing students with majors in other academic (non-life sciences, non-medical) disciplines with an overview of nutritional sciences and their applications for everyday life and health issues. This course also aims at increase the awareness of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are related to food and nutrition.The course is composed of 4 themes. Theme 1 will introduce basic concepts of nutritional sciences and the nutritional needs/concerns at different stages of life in humans. Theme 2 will address the relationship between nutrition and some common nutrition-related diseases. Weight management will also be included in theme 2. Theme 3 will discuss some diet and nutrition controversial issues. Theme 4 will cover some selected local and global nutritional issues.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:   1. identify the functions of nutrients, and symptoms resulted from excessive and deficient nutrients intake 2. recognize nutritional needs/concerns at different stages of life in humans 3. describe the relationships between nutrition and some common diseases 4. analyze nutritional controversies through applications of the basic knowledge of nutritional sciences 5. assess nutritional status using simple nutritional assessment methods 6. develop simple strategies for weight management and healthy eating habits 7. apply basic knowledge of nutritional sciences in daily life to promote healthy eating 8. identify local and global nutritional issues that influence our eating behaviors 9. increase awareness of SDGs, particularly the goals that are food and nutrition related.
syllabus: Theme 1: Understanding of Basic Nutrition (1) Functions of nutrients and their food sources;   (2) Nutritional needs/concerns at different stages of life, from pregnancy, infancy, adolescence to adults and elderly (SDG 3)   Theme 2: Nutrition, Health, and Diseases (1) Recognition of the whole spectrum of malnutrition, importance of weight management and healthy eating (SDG 3, 12)   (2) The causes and development of some common nutrition-related diseases, e.g. heart diseases, diabetes, cancer, digestive problems etc.,  (SDG 3)   Theme 3: Nutrition Myths: Facts or Fallacies (1) Effectiveness of popular diet; (2) Food and acne; (3) Organic foods; (4) Antioxidants (e.g. red wine, green tea) in relation to body health, etc.;   Theme 4: Local/Global Nutritional Issues (1) General nutritional status in HK population and the challenges in promoting health and nutrition; (2) Global nutritional issues and the relating factors, e.g. poverty and food security, agriculture production in relation to climate change, triple-burden, and food shortage, food consumption and food waste (SDG 1, 2, 3, 12, 13)

title: Biochemistry and Physical Activities
requirements: Not for Majors in Faculty of Medicine,School of LSCI; BMEG,ESHE,SPED,PESH,NSCI(YBSC,YBTC,YENS,YFNC)Majors; students taken BCHE2030,3030,3080,BIOL2120,BMEG2000,2010,LSCI1002,PHPC2007,SPED2520,2540;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course aims at providing students with some key concepts in Life Sciences, and Biochemistry in particular, through a series of daily life examples in real world situations. The course will first introduce the basic functions of our body, followed by some selected cases to illustrate how our body works during physical activities. The course is designed to let students without prior knowledge of Life Sciences acquire basic understanding and interest in Biochemistry, which can be applied in daily life in the future.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:  describe the basic functions of our body  explain the key physiological mechanisms of the human body during physical activities  apply the knowledge of Biochemistry in specific physical activities, such as sports  analyze how various environmental factors can affect the human body during physical activities  plan and to make informed judgment to respond to the injuries picked up during physical activities with the knowledge of Biochemistry
syllabus: The focus of this course is to illustrate how the key concepts in Life Sciences, in particular Biochemistry, can be applied to our daily life in real world situations. The course will first introduce the basic functions of our body, followed by the adaptation mechanisms of our body to external factors such as physical activities and environmental conditions. Selected topics on how we can actively improve our health will be covered in the second part of the course. Part 1: Basic Principles of the Functions of Our Body This part explains several important functions of our body from molecular to cellular, and from organs to systems levels so as to equip students to further understand and analyze the cases presented in the second part of the course.  The chemistry of life  Bioenergetics and material transport within the body  The skeletomuscular system  Molecular sensors of the environment and within the body  Adaptations of the body to the external environment   Part 2: Case Studies of Biochemistry in Various Life Functions This part presents several representative cases to illustrate (1) how our body maintains normal functions during physical activities and in extreme conditions and (2) how we can apply the knowledge of Biochemistry in everyday life scenarios.  How does our body respond to extreme environmental conditions? – Adaptation responses to extreme heat, cold, and oxygen level  How does our body respond to demanding physical activities? – Adaptation responses to the high energy output during a flight-or-fight reaction  How does our body utilize nutrients during physical activities? - Nutrient bioenergetics in exercise and training  What is stress and how does our body cope with it? – Hormones secreted under stress response  What happens during a sport injury? – Biochemical mechanisms of the traumatic injuries after sports  How can I feel the pain of an injury or a disease? – The mechanisms of pain and analgesia  How do I get tired and recover? – The fatigue process

title: Food Safety and Processing Technology
requirements: Not for Faculty of Medicine, School of Life Sciences Majors and Natural Sciences Majors in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC concentrations.;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: In modern cities, a wide assortment of food products is available in the markets and consumers are able to enjoy these delicious foods conveniently and safely. Behind the scenes of food enjoyment, lots of science and technology has been applied in their manufacturing processes to ensure that the food products are preserved in high standards of quality, nutrition and safety. Among those food manufacturing and processing methods, however, some of them are quite controversial and thus arouse many public concerns over food safety and security issues. This course is designed for the general students to provide them with some key concepts and scientific knowledge in food preservation, processing technology and food safety control, as well as to explore the interactive relationships between them. Through learning the basic properties of foodborne hazards, which are the origins of most food safety problems, students are able to enhance the understandings on the principles and practices of respective food preservation methods and processing technologies. Meanwhile, the potential risks and adverse effects of particular food processing technologies will be discussed. Furthermore, some highly concerning topics and incidents about food safety will be analysed based on scientific facts and discussed from different perspectives. After finishing the course, students are encouraged to use the acquired knowledge to make better food choices, distinguish the fallacies about food and appraise the impact of modern technology on human food safety and security.
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to be able to:  identify the foodborne hazards in various aspects and describe their properties  elucidate the causes and mechanisms of foodborne diseases  identify the applications of food preservation methods and technologies in daily food products and explain their working principles  apply the knowledge to make better food choices and safer domestic food preparations  analyse the contemporary food issues with scientific discipline and make informed judgment in some controversies of food concerns  appraise the pros and cons of food processing technologies and evaluate their impact on food safety and security
syllabus: This course mainly focuses on the food safety and the related processing technology. The course begins with introducing the common foodborne hazards that people come across in daily lives. Then, the principles of various contemporary food preservation methods and processing technologies protecting foods from spoilage or contamination are explicated. Finally, selected topics of food issues and safety concerns are studied. The relationship between food processing and safety are analysed through those specific discussions.   Part 1.         Foodborne Hazards             The initial part of the course provides students with a basic understanding on the biological and chemical food hazards, which are the origins of most food safety problems. The fundamental knowledge about food microorganism will be elucidated, which include the general property of microbes, the common characteristic of foodborne pathogen and the mechanism of how they cause the foodborne illnesses. On the other side, the food chemicals including toxin, allergen and contaminant that leading adverse effects to human will be introduced and some mechanisms of common food poisoning and allergy will be explained.   Biological Hazards in Food  Understanding of food microorganisms  Essential conditions for food microbe growth  Characteristics and sources of foodborne pathogens  Causes and effects of foodborne illnesses: infection and intoxication   Chemical Hazards in Food  Nature of food toxins  Existence and origins of food contaminants  Understanding of food allergens  Causes and effects of food poisoning and hypersensitive   Part 2.         Food Preservation Method and Processing Technology            This part covers the theories and practices of food preservation and safety control. The basic principles and mechanisms of modern-day food processing technologies for the preservation purpose will be explained. Moreover, the concept and principle of Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP), which is a prevalent food safety control system executing in modern food premises, will be briefly introduced in this section.   Food Processing  Principles and objectives of food processing  Effects of processing treatments on food properties       Food Preservation Method and Technology  High temperature processing: pasteurization and sterilization  Low temperature processing: chilling and freezing  Control of atmospheres in package   Control of water activity  Control of pH  Food irradiation  Functions and regulations of food additives  Hurdle Technology   Food Safety System: HACCP  Basic concept of HACCP: from farm to fork  Seven principles to develop HACCP plan for a food production  Methodology of risk assessment   Part 3. Food Issues and Concerns            Selected food issues and safety concerns will be presented in the last part of the course. The background of individual food safety topics will be introduced and the credibility of the concerns will be analysed based on the scientific knowledge and facts. The correlation between food manufacturing and safety issues will be studied. The limitations of the current food safety control system are also revealed. And the social impacts of those food safety issues will be discussed in the lesson as well.   Food Safety Topics  Foodborne outbreaks  Food frauds  Genetically modified foods  Uses of hormones and food additives

title: Chemistry: The X-Files
requirements: Not for CHEM Majors; students in concentration area of Natural Sciences Programme: Analytical and Testing Sciences; or Chemical Sciences; students who have taken CHEM2382,UGEB2380,2410,2420 ,2440;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: The course is designed to illustrate the basic principles of chemistry (e.g., atomic structure, chemical bonding, molecular properties, etc.) via case studies of some celebrated accidental discoveries (and wild claims) in science. Topics include nuclei, atoms, small molecules, radioactivity, polymers, and analytical methods in chemistry. Real-life applications and trivia are also covered.
outcome: The students would learn the basic structure of matter. They would treat “unexpected” phenomena more seriously before they discard them as fluke. They would realize the role of serendipity in discovery. Good science requires not only critical thinking but also a sense of creativity, and occasionally wild imaginations.
syllabus: Basic concepts:  atoms and molecules: their structures and roles in the formation of bulk materials  materials: important materials such as metals/alloys and polymers, their microscopic structures and applications in daily life  intermolecular forces: their origins and importance in the formation of molecules  radioactivity and nuclear processes: the phenomenon, the types and applications  organic chemistry: examples (such as polymers) and importance for industry and daily life Analytical techniques:  physical methods: (such as density and refractive index measurement) for chemical analysis
required_readings: "Serendipity: accidental discoveries in science", Royston M. Roberts, Wiley, N.Y., 1989.
recommended_readings: 「化學的故事─消失的鑽石」，田學賓等編著，台北市倚天文化事業有限公司(2005)。ISBN 980-80767-3-0

locations: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 703

title: Chemistry of Life
requirements: Not for Fac of Med; Sch of LSCI; CHEM Majors; NSCI Majors in Analy & Test Sci/ Chemical Sci concentration; students who have taken CHEM2382, UGEB2370, 2410, 2420 or 2440;Co-requisite:UGFH1000,UGFN1000or1001(only applicable to students in 4-year curr)
description: (UGEB2380 is double-coded with CHEM2382.)  This course aims to introduce the roles of chemistry in different stages of our life. 'Topics include: 1. basic chemical knowledge related to life science; 2. origin of life - essential elements. water, and proteins; 3. growing up - food. nutrients, and hormones; 4. medication: chemicals against diseases; 5. messing up - narcotics, some stimulant drugs, and hallucinogens ( e g heroin. ketamine, and ecstasy); 6. ageing; 7. the mystery of heredity - nucleic acids and the Double Helix.
outcome: Students taking this course will learn some basic chemical concepts and knowledge related to life science. They will also understand the role of chemistry in various stages of our life.
syllabus: Week 1 Introduction I Some basic concepts in chemistry will be introduced: What is chemistry? Atomic structures, isotopes, molecules and chemical bonding, physical and chemical properties of matters, physical and chemical changes.   Week 2 Introduction II Oxidation and reduction reactions, acids and bases, the Periodic Table, and a brief introduction to organic chemistry.   Week 3 Origin of Life I The essential elements and their importance to organisms water and its properties. amino acids and peptides, structures and properties of' proteins, hair-waving and the mad cow disease.   Week 4 Origin of Life II An overview on the chemistry of enzymes and the concept of stereochemistry (chirality) will he introduced   Week 5 Growing-Up I The chemical and biochemical aspects of nutrition will be discussed. An overview on carbohydrates and lipids.   Week 6 Growing-Up II An overview on vitamins. Hormones - chemical messengers in our body.   Week 7 Mid-term examination   Week 8 Medication I -Chemicals against diseases Analgesic, antibiotics and anti-viral drugs. The development of some common medicine such as aspirin and acetaminophen will be introduced. Moreover, the chemistry of antibiotics and anaesthetics will also be described.   Week 9 Medication II -Chemicals against AIDS The immune system. How far can we knock down HIV? AZT and the Cocktail Treatment.   Week 10 Messing Up-Some stimulant drugs Caffeine and nicotine as common stimulants. Cocaine, amphetamine, and ecstasy as potent stimulant drugs.   Week 11 Messing Up-Narcotics and Hallucinogens Narcotics - the three opium alkaloids: morphine, codeine, and heroin. Hallucinogens - cannabis. lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), and ketamine.   Week 12 Ageing What causes ageing? The secrets of ageing will be revealed from a molecular point of view.   Week 13 The mystery of heredity A walk through the chemistry of nucleic acids and the Double Helix,   Week 14 Nucleic acids and genetics The mystery behind genetic coding. Biosynthesis of proteins. Genetic diseases.
required_readings: J. W. Hill. S. J. Baum and R. J. Scott-Ennis, "Chemistry and Life: An Introduction to General, Organic, and Biological Chemistry," Sixth Edition, Prentice Hall, 2000.
recommended_readings: K. C. Timberlake. "General, Organic, and Biological Chemistry: Structures of Life,” Platinum Edition, Pearson Education, 2004.

title: Chemistry for a Sustainable Future
requirements:
Not for CHEM,ENSC Majors; NSCI concentration in Analytical & Testing Sciences; Chemical Sciences; or Environmental Studies; students who have taken CHEM2382, UGEB2370,2380,2410,2420 or 2440
Co-requisite:Courses with course code prefix as "UGFH" or "UGFN"
description: Chemical pollution has a substantial impact on human health and well-being. At the same time, the global demand for energy and natural resources is growing, leading to more pollution or even climate changes. In order to integrate environmental sustainability with economic growth, it is important to develop clean energy research technology, environmentally sound industrial processes and sustainable production patterns.This course is designed for students with minimal background in chemistry to acquire chemical knowledge related to sustainable development. It introduces the basic concepts of chemistry that are essential for students to understand the scientific aspects of environmental and human health challenges such as pollution and energy crisis. This course also discusses the principles of green chemistry and explain how they are applied to real-life technologies to create a sustainable future for the world.

title: Astronomy
requirements: Not for Physics Majors; students in the concentration area of Natural Sci. Programme:Physical Sci;and students taken PHYS2401, 2910, UGEB2402 or 2510.Co-requisite:UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or 1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: A qualitative and non-mathematical survey of major ideas in astronomy. Topics covered will include: earth and sky, moon, calendar and time keeping, origin of modern astronomy, light and telescope, starlight and atoms, the sun, binary stars and their significance, stellar evolution, neutron stars and black holes, Milky Way, galaxies, quasars, the structure of the universe, solar system, meteorites, asteroids and comets. This course will include one night observation. This course aims at introducing basic concepts rather than mathematical and factual details. Lectures are designed not only to present a volume of knowledge, but also to arouse students' curiosity in how nature works. Optional star-gazing trips as well as visits to Hong Kong Space Museum will be arranged.
outcome: Students are expected to - acquire a general knowledge of astronomy - be able to appreciate the beauty of the universe and also the role played by astronomy in daily life - understand the role played by astronomy in the development of science - develop a sense of how a scientist approaches a problem and applies the scientific method to seek answers - develop a critical mind by learning to confront beliefs with observations
syllabus: Part 1: Survey - The universe at different scales - Earth and the celestial sphere   Part 2: Basic principles - History of astronomy - Theory of motion and gravitation - Relativity   Part 3: The solar system   Part 4: Stars - Measuring stars - Birth, evolution and death of stars   Part 5: Cosmology - Black holes - Cosmology and astrobiology
required_readings: The lecture notes provided.
recommended_readings: Michael Seeds, "Foundations of Astronomy", 8Ih Edition. Belmont: Brooks/Cole-Thomson Learning, 2004.

title: Origins – From Cosmos to Life
requirements: Not for Physics Majors; students in the concentration area of Natural Sci Programme: Physical Sci; and students taken PHYS2401, 2910,UGEB2401 or 2510.Co-requisite:UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or 1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The course aims at providing an introduction to the formation of the cosmos and the origin of life from an astrophysical perspective. The journey starts from the origin of the universe, and leads us through all the intermediate milestones such as the appearance of matter, the formation of galaxies, the formation of stars and planets, the appearance of simple life forms, and the evolution of life on Earth. Students can thus develop a complete picture of the current understanding of the emergence of life in the cosmos, and gain perspectives of the scientific method that allows us to arrive at the knowledge.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to • recall and understand the basic idea and steps of how life comes into being in the astronomical perspective; • demonstrate their understanding of the relationship between various component topics of astrobiology; • form their opinion of the implication of the scientific knowledge of the origin of life on human’s position in the universe and the history of the universe; • gain intellectual perspectives and appreciation on the development of the astrobiology field in particular, and the multidisciplinary study of problem in general; • understand the basic principles of scientific method through examples.
syllabus: The course will start with an overview of the formation of the cosmos, the subsequent important events in the history of the universe, and the origin of life. The important milestones include 1. The origin of the cosmos. 2. The appearance of the basic form of ordinary matter (protons, neutrons, and electrons) and light elements. 3. The formation of astronomical structures (galaxy clusters, galaxies, stars). 4. The appearance of heavy elements in various stages of star evolution. 5. The formation of planets. 6. The appearance of simple and complicated molecules. 7. The emergence of elementary life forms. 8. The process of evolution on Earth and history of life. The brief overview of all these steps will provide the students with a mental map of how different pieces fit into the big picture. Then some of the major topics will be discussed in depth. For each of those chosen topics, the discussion will be about what the latest understanding is, and how we arrived at the understanding. The latter part will focus on the logical arguments in understanding observations and experiments, so that the students can develop a solid understanding of how scientific method is applied throughout the process. In particular, the topics which would be covered in depth are Topics 1, 3, 4, 5, and 8. They are chosen because we understand them the best, and because all of them can be explained in relatively simple way to non-experts. Finally, the course will cover some latest developments of the research on the various steps. Some of the results could be more speculative, and would lead to some open questions for the students. If time permits, the course will also cover some topics about the implications of the whole “story”, e.g., are we alone in the universe?

title: Chemistry in Action
requirements: Not for stud major in prog by Fac of MED;not for Chem;students in the con. areas of NatSciProg: AnaTestSci;or ChemSci; students taken CHEM2382,UGEB2370,2380,2420or2440.Co-requisite:UGFH1000,UGFN1000or1001(only applicable to stud admitted to 4year curri)
description: This course is designed for students with minimal background in Chemistry to acquire some general chemical knowledge related to our daily lives. The main objective is to acquaint students with some scientific background knowledge in chemistry. Students will be able to read about science and technology with some degree of critical judgment. This knowledge is essential for students to solve some problems in daily lives, such as to choose the right products and to compare the risk and benefits in some cases. This course will emphasize practical applications of chemistry to problems solving such as environmental pollution, energy resources, and human health. Some demonstrations will be carried out during classes.
outcome: The students in this course will learn some general chemical knowledge related to the environment and the products they encountered in their daily lives. Through this learning, the students will understand the world we live, our environment, and our body. The students will be able to do critical thinking and comparing the risks and benefits in daily Life.
syllabus: Week 1 Introduction Some general chemistry concepts will be taught, such as chemical bonding, concentration of a solution, brief introduction of atoms, elements and molecules, some organic compounds.   Week 2 Fitness and Health Athletic performance, nutrition, vitamins, minerals, muscles, exercise, sports materials.   Week 3 Oxidation and Reduction General concepts of oxidation-reduction, with examples in cut-apple, egg cooking, corrosion, photography, battery, breathalyzer used in road blocks, explosives. Demonstrations: Chemiluminescence, potato battery.   Week 4 Acid and Bases Acid strength, pH values of some common substances, common acids and bases, phosphoric acid, household products with acids or bases, neutralization reactions, antacids, acid-base buffers, the blood system, acidosis, alkalosis.  Demonstrations: Red cabbage extract - the natural indicator   Week 5 Chemistry of Household Chemicals The chemistry of surfactants, soaps and detergents, stain removal, bleach and whiteners, chemicals in dry cleaning, corrosive cleaners.   Week 6 Chemistry of cosmetics and haircare products The general chemistry of cosmetics and toiletries, creams and lotions, lipsticks and powders, sunscreen products, perfumes, deodorants, shampoos, hair perm, hair dyeing. Demonstration: ingredients in creams and lotions   Week 7 Food Additives Food preservatives, antioxidants, sequestrants, food flavours, food enhancers, pH control in foods, anticaking agents, stabilizers and thickeners. Demonstration: food colouring and other food additives   Week 8 Mid-term examination   Week 9 Toxic Substances Poisons, lethal dose, corrosive poisons, metabolic poisons, neurotoxins, teratogens, mutagens, carcinogens   Week 10 Drugs Development of medication, pharmacies, hormones used in sport, over the counter drugs, hallucination drugs, anticancer drugs, nicotine and tobacco, drug interaction   Weelk 11 Chemistry of the Environment Greenhouse effect, acid rain, ozone depletion, air pollutants, hazardous waste. Video show: "Ozone depletion"   Week 12 Energy and resources Gasoline, diesel, natural gas, solar power, hydroelectric power, wind power   Week 13 Materials - Polymers Polymers, Natural fibres, synthetic fibres, paints and adhesives, plastics and polymers
required_readings: Text books on "General Chemistly", in topics: Atomic structures, classification of matter, the Periodic Table, Molecules and Ions, Chemical Formulas, measurements, oxidation and reduction reactions, acid and base reactions.
recommended_readings: 1.   C.G Gebelein, "Chemistry and Our World" ;Wm.C. Brown Publishers, 1" Edition. 2.   C.M. Snyder, "The extraordinary Chemistry of Ordinary Things"; John Wiley & Sons, Inc. Third Edition. 3.   J.H Hill and D.K. Kolb, "Chemistry for Changing Times" ; Prentice Hall, 9' Edition.

title: Chemistry in the Kitchen
requirements: Not for stu maj in prog by Fac of Med;not for Chem;stud in con areas of NatSciProg: AnaTestSci;or Chem Sci;students who have taken CHEM2382,UGEB2370,2380,2410 or 2440. Co-requisite:UGFH1000, UGFN1000or1001 (only appli to students admitted to 4year curr)
description: The course is designed to illustrate how chemical knowledge helps demystify common phenomena in food processing, cooking and cleaning. Emphasis is given to observable changes in color, odor, taste and texture. The health aspect of chemicals encountered in the kitchen and in “health food store” will be discussed. Some of the latest technologies in cooking, cleaning and utensil materials will be introduced. The impact of cooking and cleaning methods on the environment (in terms of particulates and radiation) will be discussed. Some demonstrations will be carried out in class.
outcome: They will learn the effects of acid/bases, reduction/oxidation, protein denaturation/degradation and chemical kinetics (e.g. cooking time/temperature) on the physical appearance and the aroma/taste of prepared foodstuff. They should be more aware of chemical safety in the kitchen, as well as the health aspects of various dishes or dietary supplements. They will become more concerned with the choice of cooking utensil materials, the energy efficiencies of cooking methods and their associated environmental issues, and the proper ways in cleaning up. The more adventurous few will be able to take advantage of the chemical knowledge acquired in modifying of perfecting traditional recipes.
syllabus: Chemistry Basics: Atoms, elements & compounds Valency, covalent bonding, ionic bonding & hydrogen bonding Acids & bases (the pH scale) A layman’s view of Organic chemistry Food categories.   Bread, Cakes and Rice: Formation of gluten The function of leaveners: Yeast, baking soda & baking powder Long-grain vs short-grain rice Staling, storage & reheating. *Genetically-modified food a godsend or evil?   Fats, Oils, Butter and Margarine: Saturated, mono-unsaturated, poly-unsaturated fats The olive oil myth: why is it so expensive? Shortenings & oil-substitutes: are they suitable for daily use? Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) vs. HDL: who is the bad guy? Deep-fat frying: what are the nasty stuff? Anti-oxidants or preservatives? The debate continues What is margarine? How the trans-fat emerges? A look at hydrogenation process *Is no-fat diet good for you?   Eggs – the Natural Emulsifier: How to keep them fresh? Fried, scrambled, poached & hard-boiled eggs: how to avoid an ugly green yolk Chinese century-eggs: what can we do without lead? Custards, egg-white foams, salad dressing; Salmonellosis. *Non-stick Teflon coating is absolutely safe.   Fruits and Vegetables: Storage & ripening, taste & aroma, enzymatic browning; Nutrients: vitamin C & folic acid; Colorful presentation (It’s all in the pH) *Organic farming is a hype. *A vegetarian is a normal person.   Cuts of Meat: Light vs. dark meat How muscles cook? Cooking methods for various cuts of meat: fry, roast, poach and steam Ageing of meat & meat tenderizers Get rid of the fishy smell in steaming fish and in your fingers. *Shark cartilage soup is good for prevention of cancer. *Banning live chickens import is the way to prevent the spread of bird flu in HK.   Beverages: The bitterness & muddiness of tea & coffee Freeze-dried & decaffeinated coffee Soda pops: real sugar or sugar-substitutes? Are they carcinogenic? Alcohols: the difference between ale and lager. Wine, liquor and liqueur. Is Sake a beer or a wine? The connoisseur: the art (or is it science) of wine tasting Hangover. Over the limit: the breathalyzer *Caffeine a good guy or a bad guy? *Red wine keeps the French healthy.   Modern Cooking Methods: The electric rice cooker: how it tells if the rice is done? Microwave & infrared cooking: will the food glow in the dark? Inductive cooker (safe hotpot choice): why it works best with thin iron pot? Thermos cooking: it’s all about insulation and heat capacities of the content. *Flameless cooking is a solution to pollution.   Cleaning Up; Making water wetter than wet. Hard water? Acid to the rescue Liquid detergent vs conventional soap; Micelle formation. Drano to clear the clogged pipes: break and burn Mr Oven Clean to get rid of the stubborn burnt proteins Whiter than white illusion in laundry Dry cleaning with carbon dioxide. *Surfactants are doing more harm than good to the society.   Some Thoughts on “Health Food” What exactly are these stuff? Do we really need dietary supplements? *A silver needle is a good detector for food poisoning.
required_readings: “Chemical and Functional Properties of Food Components”, 2nd Edition, Edited by Zdzislaw E. Sikorski, CRC Press (2002) (TX545 C44)
recommended_readings: “Naturally Dangerous”, James P. Collman, University Science Books (2001) (TX531 C58)

title: Chemistry of Food and Drinks
requirements: Not for Chem;Food and Nu Sci Maj;students in the concen areas of NatSci Prog: Ana and Test Sci; or Chem Sci; students taken CHEM2382,UGEB2370, 2380,2410 or 2420.Co-requisite: UGFH1000,UGFN1000or1001 (only applicable to students admitted to 4-year curri)
description: Hong Kong is very famous for its superb cuisine, which is a fantastic fusion of eastern and western styles. Cooking is both an art and a science. Good tasting foods and drinks are the results of perfect matches of ingredients and cooking methods. Foods and drinks is related to chemistry closely. Having some understanding about the chemistry of the food ingredients and the various cooking methods can help appreciating the connections between science and human life. This course will discuss the Hong Kong cuisine culture from the chemistry perspective, to explain why these famous foods and drinks are so tasty and popular. Examples include Chinese rotisserie (Siu Mei), wonton noodles, steamed seafoods, stewed beef brisket, silk stocking milk tea, and century egg with pickled ginger, etc. Consuming food and soups that carry health and therapeutic values is also a unique food culture in China and Southeast Asia. The course will introduce several types of food that are traditionally considered to have some specific functions, and discuss their scientific justifications from the chemistry point of views. Besides, pre-packaged food and fast food is an important eating culture of modern urban people. Some important issues about pre-packaged food and fast food, such as food storage and packaging, uses of approved (and sometimes prohibited) food additives, alternative ingredients, and food testing, will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of the courses, students should be able to:  identify the connections between science and culture.  interpret the traditional and local food culture from the scientific perspectives.  explain the chemistry of the basic constituents of foods and drinks.  explain the chemical changes involved in the various cooking methods.  identify the scientifc justifications of some traditional function foods.  evaluate the commonly claimed advantages of functional foods and therapeutic diets from the science perspectives.  recognize the applications of modern science and technology in improving food productions and food safety.  describe the principles of some common food packaging methods.  acquire basic scientific grounds to judge about the validity of some misconceptions and common believes about foods and health.

title: Appreciation of Mathematics
requirements: Not for MATH; MIEG; BMED Majors; and students in the following concentration areas of NSCI Programme: Data Science, Mathematical Sciences.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The course UGEB2460 is an "appreciation" course on mathematics. As such, its emphasis is on the "appreciation" aspect and not on the detailed technicalities of mathematics.The course is designed for all students, except those majoring in Mathematics, Mathematics Education and Mathematics and Information Engineering.In this course, we outline through everyday examples how mathematicsshapes our contemporary world. These examples are based on simple, yet clever ideas which can be explained to the widest audience.It is hoped that through the course, students can get a feeling of "how mathematics works". We will look at examples from mobile phones, from GPS, computer graphics, ATM machines, voting systems, forensic detection of accounting forgery, computer graphics, Escher's paintings, quasicrystals, world atlas constructions etc.
outcome: Appreciate the historical background, in specific examples of key mathematical ideas which are related to innovative objects used by the human society in the last four centuries.    Comprehend, if deemed possible, some of these mathematical ideas behind many math-related objects in our daily life.    Recognize and analyze mathematical ideas in some other gadgets motivated by mathematics.    Acquire a rudimentary knowledge of artistic and mathematical vocabulary which could then be applied to discuss (both orally and in writing) ideas presented in the course Evaluate the importance of the role which mathematics plays in our daily life.
syllabus: The concept and its evolution from the Antiquity to present day    Different types of numbers and their applications    How clever manipulation leads to better applications – examples from arithmetic and geometry etc.    Simple counting    Rubber Sheet Geometry    Logic and why it is useful in the internet world    Rethinking why we learn mathematics
required_readings: According to teaching plan of teaching staff concerned, reading assignments may subject to modifications as deemed necessary.  COMAP. For All Practical Purposes: Mathematical Literacy in Today's   World. W.H. Freeman, 2013. title: Perspectives in Risk Management and Modern Society
requirements: Not for RMSC,STAT,QFRM Majors; students in the following concentration areas of Natural Sciences Programme: Data Science; or Mathematical Sciences; and students who have taken RMSC2001;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: Risk management is without doubt one of the most important issues in various aspects of the modern society. Quantifying risk management is not only a management tool, but is also a scientific activity. This course aims at introducing the role of risk management in modern society. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the role of risk management and its impact on every day life both at personal and institutional level.
outcome: This course develops the students' basic concepts of risk management in broad terms. After the course, the students are expected:                to understand the evolution of risk management science in the modem society (T1, T2, T6).                to identify and evaluate potential risks in daily life (T1, T3).                to develop a systematic, although conceptual, approach in handling various types of risks in life and work (T3, T4, T5).                to appreciate the need of continuous development in risk management techniques to adapt the ever-changing economical and social environment (T1, T6).      Topics:   T1: Basic risk management concepts: classification, identification, evaluation.   T2: Economic theories underlying risk management.   T3: Risk management in daily life: e.g. health risk and retirement risk.   T4: Risk management using insurance.   T5: Risk management using financial derivatives.   T6: A case study of risk management evolution in modern society.
syllabus: This course aims at providing a focused introduction to various concepts of risks and risk measures from ascientific perspective. The course will discuss on various roles that risk plays in our modern society. Topics include:   1. The evolution and development of modern risk management practice. The shift in philosophy from solely insurance buying for pure risks to integrated risk management for much broader scope of risks. Related concepts, such as perils, hazards and adverse selection, will also be discussed through various real life examples; 2. Classification and identification of risks. We shall use daily life examples to arouse students’ sensitivity to risks. 3. Risk management techniques such as risk avoidance, risk control and risk financing. 4. Basic principles underlying insurance. We shall introduce the development of this traditional risk management tool for new and complicated types of risks, such as terrorism and natural disasters. 5. Banking industry experienced significant and continuous changes in their ways of handling risks. We shall discuss the history of this evolution as an example of the development of risk management concept. 6. Case studies (e.g. SARS, Hurricane Katrina, 911 attacks) will be discussed in order to illustrate the risks in different aspects of our life and the appropriate tools to manage it.
required_readings: Chan, N.H. (2004). 風險管理精義，明報出版社，香港 Borge, Dan (2001) The book of Risk, Wiley.
recommended_readings: Walsh, James (1998) True odds: how risk effects your everyday life, Silver Lake Pub. Dorfman, Mark (2005) Introduction to Risk Management and Insurance, Prentice Hall.

title: Human Evolution
requirements: UGEB2502 is double-coded with ANTH2810. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2810. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEB2502 is double-coded with ANTH2810.)  What does it mean to be human? Where did we come from? Where are we going? This course investigates long-term evolutionary perspectives on the human species. The basics of evolution and natural selection as scientific theories are clearly set out and examined, and common misconceptions discussed. Evidence for the evolution of mammals and primates is reviewed and discussed, and the common characteristics of these species are highlighted, demonstrating the connections between humans and other forms of life. The course covers what we know about human ancestors and the evolution of modern humans. Students are introduced to the wide range of human adaptations to local conditions across contemporary cultures and the variety of relationships that human populations have with the environment. Students are encouraged to use the knowledge they have acquired to ask: are these relationships always sustainable? Looking to the future: what are our responsibilities both to future generations of humans and towards other species with which we share our world? This course aims to give students an understanding and appreciation of evolutionary perspectives on the place of humans in the world, the variety of contemporary human societies, and a broad perspective on the complexity of the relationship between humans, the environment and other species.
outcome: In this course students learn about the nature of scientific theories and their development, as well as the use of evidence in evaluating hypotheses. Students are also exposed to the potential for misunderstandings of scientific theory and the distinction between fact and value. Comparative abilities are emphasised through reviewing common features of the life-course of a variety of animals and the influence of animal habitats, with particular focus on closely related primate species.   The history of human evolution is introduced to students, focussing on the emergence of universal capacities such as language, technology, art and culture. Students are encouraged to learn about and appreciate the variety of human cultures and the flexibility of humans in adapting to local environments. A comparative perspective on human culture is encouraged through a focus on the common subsistence needs of all humans, and the variety of practices by which these needs are met.   Students are exposed to a wide perspective on the place of the human species in the world. They are encouraged to exercise long-term evaluations of, and exercise a sense of judgement about the impact and sustainability of human action, both in relation to the environment and other species as well as future generations of the human species. Students are thus encouraged to think about their own place in society.
syllabus: Weekly Topics   Week 1    Introduction: Orientation and Course Overview Week 2    Evolution and Natural Selection 1: History of the Idea Week 3    Evolution and Natural Selection 2: Mechanisms, Examples and Some Common Misunderstandings (Teleology and Determinism) Week 4    Evolution of Mammals and Primates: History, Defining Characteristics and Current Diversity Week 5    Characteristics of Living Primates Week 6    African Apes and Hominid Origins Week 7    Human Ancestors Week 8    [Mid-term] Week 9    The Emergency of Modern Humans 1: Debates, Methods of Study and The Use of Evidence Week 10  The Emergence of Modern Humans 2: Technologies and Art Week 11  Human Adaptability to Local Conditions Week 12  Varieties of Human Subsistence Week 13  Humans and our Environments Today Week 14  Sustainability and Survival

title: Deciphering the Past: Culture, Archaeology and Science
requirements: UGEB2505 is double-coded with ANTH2740. ;Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2740. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEB2505 is double-coded with ANTH2740.) How we understand the past defines the way how we understand our current situation. Archaeology is a dynamic discipline that has tremendously expanded our knowledge about the past, but this subject is not just about digging and doing fieldwork. A wide range of new techniques (e.g., metallurgy, zoology, and 3d stimulation) and research methods have been incorporated into current archaeological research, and eventually transformed the understanding of ourselves and our culture in many ways. This course provides a general introduction in terms of two specific domains: 1) basic archaeological science that changed the research paradigm of human culture and history; 2) an overall history about ancient technology illustrated by new research techniques to explain how this modern world took shape. Moreover, this course provides hands-on practice to cultivate students’ cross-disciplinary research skills and prepare them for the arrival of a new, digitalized research era.
outcome: #1    Understand what is “scientific reasoning”, and be able to evaluate claims about the past by combining anthropological knowledge and understanding of scientific techniques; #2   General understanding about the history of technology and basic knowledge background to appreciate technological achievements in the past; #3   Equip students with skills to conduct digital humanities research and foundation to develop cross-disciplinary study; #4     Inspire students of different backgrounds to employ new techniques addressing problems challenging most cultural heritage projects that our current society is encountering.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction   What is archaeological science and the archaeological way of the thinking?   No reading for this week   Week 2: Can we study aliens in the past?   What is the philosophy of science and pseudoarchaeology?    Week 3: Truth and fallacies in numbers   An introduction to quantitative research and sampling in archaeology    Week 4: Deciphering the secret of our meat   A basic introduction to zooarchaeology   Week 5: Deciphering the secret of our staple foods   A basic introduction to archaeobotany and early globalization of food   Week 6: Deciphering the secret of ancient space and landscape   A basic introduction to spatial technology and satellite images to understand how people lived in the past    Week 7: Deciphering the microscopic world   A basic introduction to microscopic techniques and chemical analytical methods   Week 8: Mid-term exam   Week 9: Deciphering the ancient industrial world   A basic introduction to mineral exploitation and difference between ancient and modern mining    Week 10: Deciphering the secrete of ancient ceramics   A basic introduction to the manufacturing techniques of ceramics and impacts of pyrotechnology in human history   Week 11: Deciphering the secrete of ancient bronze   A basic introduction to ancient bronze technology and formation of early bronze trade   Week 12: Deciphering the secrete of ancient metal objects (gold, silver and iron)   A basic introduction to other ancient meter technology (e.g., iron) and early commodity exchange   Week 13: Can scientific methodology help save the past?   A basic introduction to techniques in cultural heritage conservation

title: The Stars and Our Lives
requirements: Not for majors in Faculty of Engineering, Faculty of Science; not for MIEG,BMED,QFRM Majors; and students who have taken PHYS2401, UGEB2401 or 2402;Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: The course aims at studying the human exploration of astronomical phenomena in the history, thereby disclosing the interplay between astronomical activities and the cultural, social, and scientific aspects of human lives, as well as the deep and authentic relation between the celestial bodies and the lives on earth. Topics include: astronomical traditions of ancient civilizations and their social functions, astronomical phenomena found in ancient books, literature, myths and their scientific explanations; the impact of scientific revolutions in the Renaissance and the 20th century on our views of the universe, human thought and modern civilization, the influence of cosmic events on the lives on earth, the quest for extraterrestrial lives. Star-gazing activity is included to enhance students’ interest. The course is designed to help students with little or no science background gain intellectual perspectives on the interplay between science and culture, and our subtle relation with the universe.
outcome:              Students gain a understanding of the interplay between the astronomical traditions of ancient civilizations and their cultural and social backgrounds.              Students gain intellectual perspectives on the history of science, the interplay between science and other human activities, and the impacts of science on human thoughts and modern civilization.              Students acquire some basic knowledge in astronomy, gain a understanding of our position in the universe, and our deep and subtle relation with various cosmic events.              Students gain intellectual perspectives on the modern astronomical discoveries and their implications on our views of the universe.              Arouse students' curiosity and stimulate their imagination on the mysteries of the universe, thus providing some motivation for life-long learning.              Students gain hands-on experience in star-gazing and he motivated to learn more about the cultural and historical aspects of science.
syllabus:              Cosmic tour: A virtual journey to the cosmos using the 'Powers of Ten' approach. Our position in the universe and the hierarchy of celestial bodies [l, 2, 3].                The sky and our lives: Common astronomical phenomena such as the apparent motions of the stars and the sun, seasons, lunar phases, eclipses, precession, their scientific explanations and relations to our lives, star-gazing and amateur astronomy, western astronomical traditions and mythology of the night sky [l, 2, 4]                Chinese astronomical tradition and culture: Chinese astronomical traditions throughout the history, its cultural, social, and astrological origins, the social functions of astronomical activities, astronomical phenomena in ancient books, literature and their implications, the scientific and non-scientific aspects of Chinese astronomical traditions [1, 5, 6]                Western astronomy and the modern world: Ancient Greeks astronomy, Medieval Islamic astronomy and their scientific basis, Renaissance astronomy and its impacts on science, scientific methods, human thought, and modern civilization; revolution in physics and astronomy in the 20th century and its influence on our views of the universe; modern cosmology from the physical science points of view [1, 2, 7, 8]                Cosmic events and our destiny: Cosmic events including Big Bang, the evolution of stars, impacts of asteroids and comets on earth, and their relations to the origin, evolution and destruction of lives on the Earth [l, 3, 8, 9]

title: Games and Strategic Thinking
requirements: Not for MATH; MIEG; BMED; students in the concen areas of Natural Sci Prog: Data Sci; or Mathematical Sci; and students taken ECON3160 or MATH4250.Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or 1001 (only applicable to students admitted to 4-year curriculum)
description: The aim of this course is to study games and strategies from the mathematical perspective. We investigate the manner in which rational people interact when there are competitions. This applies to parlour games and more importantly to economy, social psychology, politics and business. We will introduce the great discoveries of Von Neumann and Nash, and discuss their impact on society. Also, we will use examples of various types of games to illustrate how some basic mathematical methods can lead to optimal strategies for decision making.
outcome: We expect students to learn how to formulate real life problems that involve strategic interaction as mathematical games, and to be able to use the appropriate mathematical tools to study such games. We expect students to be able to: Understand the concepts of a game, such as players, positions, moves, strategies, information, rationality, game trees, outcomes, payoffs, zero-sum and non-zero-sum games, Pareto optimality, equilibrium, sequential games, cooperative games. Formulate and solve simple matrix games, and to use them for investigating practical situations. Appreciate how game theory may be applied in other fields of knowledge, such as economics, political science, biology, and how it may be applied in decision making processes, such as auction pricing, cost allocations problems, military planning, diplomacy. Be aware of the aims, scope and limitations of game theory.
syllabus: Core content: Basic concepts: players, positions, moves, strategies, information, rationality, game trees, outcomes, payoffs, zero-sum and non-zero-sum games. Equilibrium concepts: Solution to a game, Pareto optimality, dominant strategy equilibrium, Nash equilibrium, Prisoner Dilemma. Two-person zero-sum games, two-person non-zero sum games, and their applications.Selected topics: Sequential games; complete and incomplete information games and their applications. Cooperative and non-cooperative games, N-person games and their applications. Combinatorial games.Relevant mathematical tools, such as matrices, probability and graphs, will be developed in the course.
required_readings: J. Bewersdorff: Luck, Logic and White Lies: the Mathematics of Games. A K Peters 2005. P.D. Straffin: Game Theory and Strategy.Mathematical Association of America 1993.
recommended_readings: M. Bacharach: Economics and the theory of games. Macmillan 1976.   白波: 博奕智慧：經商必讀手冊 (Wisdom of game). 德威國際文化事業有限公司2006.  K. Binmore: Essays on the Foundations of Game Theory. Basil Blackwell 1990.  K. Binmore: Fun and Games - A Text on Game Theory. D.C. Heath and Company 1992.  R. Gardner: Games for business and economics. Wiley 2003.  S. Vajda: Mathematical games and how to play them. Ellis Horwood 1992.

title: Perspectives in Meteorology
requirements:
Not for Physics; and Earth System Science Majors; students in the following concentration area of Natural Sciences Programme: Physical Sciences.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: An introduction to meteorological phenomena and mechanisms. This course aims at a non-mathematical exposition of the central ideas of meteorological study. The interaction between the climate and human activities will also be discussed. Topics include atmospheric phenomena such as general circulation, storms and typhoons, forecasting, oceanic processes, El Nino and La Nina and global climate changes.
outcome: Students are expected to:   - gain a perspectives of scientific approach in solving problems and how the real    systems such as weather and climate can be tackled by scientific methods,   - acquire some knowledge about the mechanisms of various phenomena in    meteorology,   - develop a perspective of the relations between weather/climate and the human    society,   - develop a perspective of how the environment of the earth is influenced by the    interaction between different parts of Nature and human activities,    - develop a perspective of how knowledge can be gained, how scientific way can    help to analyse and make forecast among uncertainties.   - aware the critical role of human race in the future of the earth,
syllabus: Week 1           Introduction to the Atmosphere                                Composition, greenhouse effect, structure, evolutionWeek 2            Solar radiation and energy balance                                The sun, seasons, energy balance and temperatureWeek 3-4         Moisture, clouds, and precipitation                                Humidity and saturation, stability, clouds, precipitationWeek 4-5        Wind and atmospheric circulation                                Air pressure, winds, measurement, global circulation, air masses, fronts, jet streams,Week 5&6       Thunder storm and tornadoes, tropical cyclones                                Formation, structure, tracking, powerWeek 7&8       Planetary atmospheres and weathers                                Weather and climate on Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, . . .Week 9-10       Lightning and optical phenomena                                Formation of lightning, rainbow, halo, aurora, green flash, . . .Week 10-11     Weather forecasting                                 Forecasting and modeling, services and operations of Hong Kong ObservatoryWeek 11-12     Global climate change                                Past climates, mechanisms, methods to know about the past climates, case studies: El Nino and La Nina, . . .Week 12-14     Global crisis - ozone depletion and global warming                                Ozone hole, effect on human, public policy, current events and future prospects; Runaway greenhouse effect, evidence of global warming, effect of global warming, the Kyoto Protocol, other hypotheses

title: Perspectives in Material Science
requirements: Not for PHY; CHEM; students in the following concen areas of NatSci Prog: Ana and Test Sci; Chem Sci; or Phy Sci. Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 1001 (only applicable to students admitted to 4-year curri)
description: Undoubtedly, materials science is a backbone in our modern technologies ranging from the construction of a lightweight supersonic aircraft to the fabrication of a microprocessor in supercomputer. This course aims to deliver a general survey of materials science to students without a strong physical science background. Some of the topics include: metals, polymers, ceramics, composites, and semiconductors. Their properties, structures, processing techniques, applications, and together with those of the modern advanced materials, will be presented.
outcome: Students are expected to: 1. acquire some knowledge to classify different types of materials. 2. know various approaches in materials investigations. 3. be able to understand why some materials can be used and some cannot. 4. develop a perspective of relating materials to human development and society. 5. have more awareness in environmental issues while using or disposing materials. 6. know what sorts of materials are being used in some hi-tech applications.
syllabus: Introduction:              Differences between pure and applied sciences, materials science and engineering              History of materials, periodic tables and natural elements              Classification of materials   Metals:              History of metals              Structures and properties of metals              Polycrystalline and single crystalline              Metallography: methods of studying metals              Phase diagrams              Mechanical properties              Crystal defects and dislocations   Polymers:              Polymers and environment              Dioxin              Types of polymers: natural polymers and synthetic polymers              General properties              Thermoplastics, thermosets and elastomers              Rubber and vulcanization              Recycling              Forming processes in polymers productions   Ceramics:              Definitions of ceramics              Comparison of ceramics to other materials              Traditional and advanced ceramics, civilization and human development              Structures              Properties and applications              Ceramics used in automobiles and space shuttles   Composites              Definitions              Properties and applications              Metal-based and ceramic-based composites              Parts in automobiles   Semi-conductors:              Electrons and holes carriers              Electrical behaviors              Optical behaviors              Bands structures              Products and applications

Hummel, "Understanding materials science", New York, Springer, 2004. 3.
