title: Everyday Computing and the Internet
requirements: Not for Computer Science Majors; and Computer Engineering Majors.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The University of Hong Kong (HKU), The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST), and The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU) are partners in a joint project entitled “The Responsive Universities: Appreciating Content Sharing in General Education”, which is funded by the UGC Funding Scheme for Teaching and Learning Related Proposals in the 2016-19 Triennium. Arising from this joint project, the four universities enter into an Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional General Education Course Enrolment, under which students in the four universities can enrol in a list of designated General Education courses respectively offered by the four universities. This course, offered by The University of Hong Kong, is one of the designated courses under the Agreement.By confirming your enrolment of the course, you agree to give consent to CUHK in sharing your personal data among the partner institution of the Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional Course Enrolment among HKU, CUHK, HKUST and PolyU, and to the partner institution for releasing your grades or other information relating to your study of the course to CUHK.In order to make informed decisions in this information age, everyone needs to have an efficient way to sift through and evaluate the myriads of information that is available through the Internet. The ultimate objective of this course is to help students develop a “computational” state of mind for everyday events. Specifically, the course will enable students to answer the following questions: What daily problems need to be solved by a computational method? Are such problems solvable? By what means can such problems be solved? Is it worthwhile to compute such problems? How do all these problems relate to the Internet that we use on a daily basis? We will also discuss intensively the societal impacts of computing technologies on our daily life. The course will be taught with minimal levels of mathematical and technical detail.Online lectures would be available for the whole course, making room for more in-depth learning in lecture sessions. Specifically, four to five lecture sessions would be conducted in collaborative workshop formats, whereby students need to work in teams to complete hands-on tasks corresponding to the topics covered in the course.

title: Electronic Technologies in Everyday Life
requirements: Not for Electronic Engineering Majors. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The University of Hong Kong (HKU), The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST), and The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU) are partners in a joint project entitled “The Responsive Universities: Appreciating Content Sharing in General Education”, which is funded by the UGC Funding Scheme for Teaching and Learning Related Proposals in the 2016-19 Triennium. Arising from this joint project, the four universities enter into an Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional General Education Course Enrolment, under which students in the four universities can enrol in a list of designated General Education courses respectively offered by the four universities. This course, offered by The University of Hong Kong, is one of the designated courses under the Agreement.By confirming your enrolment of the course, you agree to give consent to CUHK in sharing your personal data among the partner institution of the Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional Course Enrolment among HKU, CUHK, HKUST and PolyU, and to the partner institution for releasing your grades or other information relating to your study of the course to CUHK.From digital computers, smart mobile phones, Apple watch to many modern gadgets like intelligent robots and automonous vehicles, electronic technologies have become an indispensable part of our everyday life. In order to make informed decisions as to whether we should adopt these ever-changing electronic technologies, we have to develop a basic understanding of the principles, “substances” and cost-benefit considerations behind them. This course aims to: (i) arouse students’ general interest in science and technology, particularly with regard to current “high-tech” electronic products that they encounter every day; and (ii) enable students to develop critical intellectual enquiries concerning existing and latest electronic technologies they encounter in their everyday lives through lectures, discussions and hands-on experimentation. At the end of the course, students will not only be able to recognize how electronics works, but also be able to understand their social implications, as well as to develop critical thinking and to carry educated discussion about merits and common misconceptions associated with new technologies. The hands-on experiments will also allow the student to have the experience and some confidence in handling electronic components to solve a real problem using electronic technology.

title: The Science of Crime Investigation
requirements: Not for LLB; and Double Degree Programme of Bachelor of Business Administration and Juris Doctor (BAJDN) Majors. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: The University of Hong Kong (HKU), The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK), The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST), and The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU) are partners in a joint project entitled “The Responsive Universities: Appreciating Content Sharing in General Education”, which is funded by the UGC Funding Scheme for Teaching and Learning Related Proposals in the 2016-19 Triennium. Arising from this joint project, the four universities enter into an Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional General Education Course Enrolment, under which students in the four universities can enrol in a list of designated General Education courses respectively offered by the four universities. This course, offered by The University of Hong Kong, is one of the designated courses under the Agreement.By confirming your enrolment of the course, you agree to give consent to CUHK in sharing your personal data among the partner institution of the Agreement for Collaboration in Cross-institutional Course Enrolment among HKU, CUHK, HKUST and PolyU, and to the partner institution for releasing your grades or other information relating to your study of the course to CUHK.This course introduces students to the scientific, legal and ethical concepts that underpin forensic science. Forensic science spans all scientific disciplines such as anthropology, biology, chemistry, computing, medicine, physics, etc. Students will explore and develop an understanding of the principles of forensic science through an overview as well as more topic-specific lectures, and experience hands-on tutorials involving scientific analysis of forensic evidence. Knowledge gained will be applied and assessed through individual tasks as well as a collaborative project on as assigned case.

title: Perspectives in Medical Sciences
requirements: Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Medicine. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course aims to provide the structural and functional bases as well as the new advances at the molecular and cellular levels for the understanding of how our body works and adapts to changes in the internal and external environment, such as imbalance of chemicals and hormones, extreme alterations in temperature and pressure, as well as after mutation and during aging. In addition, development of knowledge about the causes of disorders in the body and what drugs and new therapeutic approaches can be used for treatment are also areas of focus.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to:     Describe the basic human body structures, their functions, and related clinical issues.    Describe how the body regulates itself to encounter both internal and external changes and the consequences if it fails to do so.    Write the relevance and importance of advances in medical sciences to the well-being of mankind.    Read, analyse, and criticise both the general and research articles related to the human body and health issues.    Use different resources such as library and internet to search for body and health related information.    Comment and critique on the controversies and ethical issues that come with the latest advances in medical sciences.
syllabus: The course is roughly divided into two blocks with the first half mainly introducing the perpetuation of life and maintenance of the life processes and the second half emphasizing more on the health issues and physical disorders. All lectures will be conducted by teachers from the School of Biomedical Sciences. Each lecture will start by introducing some basic knowledge of the topics and then move into relating its relevance to the understanding of disease conditions. The impact of some latest advances in medical sciences on mankind will also be discussed. Perpetuation of life and maintenance of life processes Medical sciences help us to better understand the upholding of the healthy, normal status of our body. The seven lectures in this area will illustrate the general anatomical and physiological concepts for understanding the sophisticated yet highly coordinated mechanisms involved in the conception of life and normal functioning of the human body. Topics include:         Topics     Learning Contents       Fertility and infertility    Reproduction is essential for the continued existence of a species. This lecture provides a brief overview on the physiological control of gamete production in men and women, and various factors that determine fertility and contribute towards infertility. Various methods of contraception and how they work will be introduced.      Miracle of life    This lecture gives an account of the human reproductive system and the prenatal development of the human embryo inside mother’s womb. It covers the human embryonic development starting from a fertilized egg which then grows to a cluster of cells and gradually changes and develops into a fetus during pregnancy. It also touches on test-tube baby and techniques for assisted reproduction.      A beautiful mind: wonders of the brain    Our memories, emotions and actions determine who we are. All these are functions of the brain and this lecture will reveal the important features of this mysterious anatomical structure.      Body composition and body fluid    Water makes up of about 60% of our body weight. The various functions of water in humans and the physiological regulation of total body water volume and its contents will be outlined.      Cardiovascular diseases and treatments    Cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension and ischemic heart diseases are the most prevalent medical conditions in the Western society. This lecture will briefly cover the organization and physiological control of the cardiovascular system. Besides, the common causes of cardiovascular diseases and the basis of current drug treatments will be introduced.      Wireless control in our body: hormones    Hormones are chemical messengers which act as wireless control of life processes in the human body. Travelling from the site of synthesis to distant target tissues or organs via the bloodstream, hormones can exert widespread influences over a long distance. In this lecture, the control and function of various endocrine systems, as well as the causes and symptoms of common endocrine diseases will be discussed.      Life at the extremes    Majority of the human population live in areas close to sea level. The body is highly adapted to the air pressure and oxygen content at this altitude. When a lowlander ascends, the pressure becomes lower and oxygen content reduces, body has to adapt to this new environment. A highlander lives at high altitude for thousands of years and their physical performance is much better than a fully adapted lowlander. The physiological and genetic adaptation process will be described.      Health issues and physical disorders An understanding of the body defense system and disease mechanisms is important for the maintenance of health and the choice of effective treatments. The pathophysiological mechanisms involved in physical disorders induced by deterioration of normal physiological functions or by exposure of the body to foreign substances/organisms will be examined. Topics included:          Topics    Learning Contents      Body defense    Our defense system is a body-wide network consisting of organs, tissues, cells, and small molecules that work together to fight against “foreign” invaders and different kinds of stressors. This lecture aims to introduce the mechanism of body defense and response to infection as one source of body immune reaction. The common hospital-acquired infections and epidemiology will also be discussed.      Targeting our genes    In human, genetic codes are stored in DNA. The human genome contains 3 billion base pairs of nucleotides. Any mutations in the DNA sequence may lead to genetic diseases. The goal of the Human Genome Project is to determine the complete DNA sequence in human. In this lecture, basic knowledge of genetics as well as the causes of genetic diseases will be introduced, and the importance of the human genome project in the study of genetic diseases will be discussed. Enormous progress on genome editing has been made in the past few years. The genome editing tools and prospects of this technology will also be discussed.      Avoiding the top killer - cancer    Cancer is a major killer disease that has long haunted mankind. Carcinogenesis refers to the development of cancerous cells from normal cells. In this lecture, different causes of carcinogenesis and the impact of human activities on the development of cancer will be discussed.      Drugs that we take    This lecture aims to provide students with a basic understanding on what are drugs, how they are discovered, and how they work. General pharmacological principles which are important for understanding the proper use of drugs as medicines will be discussed. Drug abuse and its harmful effects will also be described.      Healthy aging    Aging is a natural process that causes a gradual slowdown of body function and increases the risk of developing diseases. This lecture will explore the effects of aging on different body functions and discuss the strategies that can be used to delay the process of aging and prepare the body and mind for a healthy aging.

title: Perspectives in Clinical Sciences
requirements: Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Medicine. ;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course aims to provide a general education on medical knowledge, so that students can have a basic understanding on several common diseases that can be encountered in daily life, especially the physiological and biochemical mechanisms behind the development of the diseases. To better illustrate some general aspects of medicine, this course is enriched by topics of medical research and informatics. Students coming from non-medical background may acquire general knowledge of the scientific basis of diseases and their related management as common people in the community. Students would find the medical information gained in this course useful in their daily life.
outcome: After completing this course, students will be able to: 1. describe the causes of diseases that are commonly found in Hong Kong; 2. explain the strategies for the disease prevention; 3. appreciate the most up-to-date technologies in disease diagnosis and treatment; 4. criticize the ethical issues related to abortion and stem cell research; 5. practice skills for searching and selecting useful information from scientific journals using the web-based search engine "Pubmed"; 6. integrate the knowledge learnt from lectures in essay writing;     7. comment on recent advancement in biotechnology development; 8. propose possible directions of clinical sciences development in the future.
syllabus: Course Outline: Four major areas will be covered in this course. Three selected topics of interest will be given under a major area, and each one of them both from a scientific perspective and a clinical perspective.       Areas    Topics    Lecture Contents      Molecular coding of life    Prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests       Science:   Genetic codes and genetic diseases.  Clinical:    Clinical considerations and approaches of prenatal diagnosis.      Stem cells and tissue regeneration       Science:   Different types of stem cells and their differentiation potentials.  Clinical:    Potential medical applications of stem cells.      Sense and sensibility    Science:   A look at the human body: the five senses.  Clinical:    Common problems in development.      Growing up    Allergy         Science:   The immune system in our body.  Clinical:    Common types of allergy in Hong Kong and their treatment.      Obesity         Science:   Causes and health risks associated with obesity.  Clinical:    Obesity: What should patients and health providers do?      Gastric problems              Science:   Gastric acid secretion: principles and regulation.  Clinical:    Common upper digestive diseases.      The invaders    Hepatitis B and liver cancer    Science:   Cell cycle, apoptosis and cancer.  Clinical:    The symptoms, diagnosis, treatment and prevention of hepatitis B infection.      Influenza    Science:   Biology of the influenza virus.  Clinical:    The symptoms, diagnosis, treatment and prevention of influenza.      HIV and AIDS    Science:   Biology of human immunodeficiency virus.  Clinical:    HIV: from science to medicine.      Growing old    Arthritis       Science:   Purine degradation and gouty arthristis.  Clinical:    Diagnosis and management of arthritis.      Osteoporosis       Science:   Bone metabolism and calcium balance.  Clinical:    Osteoporosis: epidemiology, diagnosis and treatment.      Alzhemier's disease    Science:  The human nervous system.  Clinical:   Pathology of Alzheimer's disease and their treatment.          Course Details and References:   A.     Molecular coding of life   The development from a fertilized egg to a normal functioning human being is a miraculous process. All animals begin life as a fertilized egg. After several round of cell division, the fertilized egg will develop into an embryo, and then a fetus. During development, stem cells can differentiate into different types of cells in our body. Each cell inherits the same set of DNA, but only selected genes are activated. However, any error in the genetic code will result in defects and pathological changes. Currently, prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests are employed to detect these defects. With the diagnosis of such defects, we could devise therapeutic interventions or other treatment regimens to minimize the impacts of these defects. Besides genetic diseases, some common problems might also arise during childhood development, like hearing and speech impairment, visual impairment, delay for motor skills, and mental retardation.   1.      Prenatal diagnosis and genetic disease tests   The genetic code is hidden in DNA. The genetic information stored in the DNA sequence is transferred through mRNA and then finally to proteins. When there are mutations in the DNA sequences, genetic diseases may arise. Prenatal diagnosis is very important in increasing the chance of delivering a healthy baby.    2.      Stem cells and tissue regeneration     The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2012 was awarded to Sir John B. Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka for the discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent stem cells.  This discovery is an important breakthrough in medicinal research. In this lecture, the definition and characteristics of stem cells will be introduced. Methods for stem cell preparation and the potential applications of stem cells for medical therapy will be explained. Current problems and ethical issues on stem cell usage will be discussed.    3.      Sense and sensibility   The molecular and cellular basis of different sensation will be introduced. Common sensory disorders and the effects on childhood development will be explained. Current advances in diagnosis and treatment will be discussed.       B.     Growing up   The immune system in our body helps to protect us against disease by identifying and killing any pathogens from entering the body. However, over-reactivity of this life-saving system will cause allergy that will make troubles for us. Allergic diseases that are commonly found in Hong Kong, like rhinitis and asthma, will be introduced.   Beside allergic diseases, other problems may arise when we grow up from childhood and enter into adulthood. In the past, under-nutrition is a problem in many parts of the world. Nowadays, the problems of over-nutrition and unbalanced diet are becoming more serious in many countries.   Coupled with the lack of exercise, obesity is a common problem among many working adults in Kong Kong. Also, a stressful working environment together with the bacterial infection has made gastric problems commonplace in Hong Kong. If we continue to neglect the warning signals from our bodies, we may finally suffer from lethal organ failure.  1.      Allergy  The immune system protects us against disease by killing the pathogens that enter our body. Disorders of immune system occur when the immune response is hypersensitive, or lacking. Allergy is an immune response excited by allergens. Allergens that are commonly found in Hong Kong include house dust mite, cockroaches, and house moulds.    2.   Obesity   This topic will discuss diet, energy balance, healthy body weight, life styles, genetics and environmental factors in relation to overweight and obesity. It will also emphasize how obesity increases the risk of chronic diseases. The methods to treat obesity will be briefly introduced, including dietary intervention, behavior modification, medications and surgery.   3.     Gastric problems  The Nobel Prize in Physiology & Medicine for 2005 was awarded to Barry J. Marshall and J. Robin Warren for establishment of the linkage between Helicobacter pylori and gastric diseases. The bacteria colonized in the stomach induce many changes in gastric secretion. This topic will address the basic science and clinical manifestation of gastric diseases.      C.     The invaders     The human race is in a state of constant battle with our environment. This struggle for survival includes the fight against microorganisms in the environment. In the past, bacterial infections caused much mortality and morbidity to the human race. With the development of antibiotics, this problem is now under control. However, we are less successful in the development of effective anti-viral drugs. Thus, viral infection has become a serious problem. In this part, three viral infected diseases will be introduced. These include influenza (caused by influenza virus), hepatitis B (caused by hepatitis B virus), and acquired immune deficiency syndrome (caused by human immunodeficiency virus).     1.      Hepatitis B and liver cancer     In Hong Kong, it was estimated that about 10% of the whole population are hepatitis B carriers. The long-term consequences of chronic viral hepatitis infection include liver cancer, chronic liver diseases and cirrhosis. Local studies showed that approximately 80% of patients with liver cancer were hepatitis B carriers. In this module, the relationship between hepatitis B virus and liver diseases will be explored.     2.      Influenza     The annual epidemic and the potential threat of a pandemic render influenza a major infectious disease in the world. Effective control of influenza entails a combination of good sanitary habits and the employment of effective vaccines, diagnostic tests and antiviral drugs.     3.      HIV and AIDS     Acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) is caused by human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. According to the statistics from the World Health Organization, AIDS accounts for the highest number of deaths in the world. In this module, the structure and organization of HIV, the route of transmission of AIDS, as well as the diagnosis and therapy of AIDS will be discussed.      D.     Growing old   Aging is a natural process of all human beings. Associated with aging, many physiological aspects of the body would start to deteriorate. These include the deterioration of joint functions (which will lead to arthritis), bone functions (which will lead to the development of osteoporosis), and brain functions (which will lead to the development of Alzheimer’s disease). The proper management of these conditions is a concern for the aging population.     1.      Arthritis   Arthritis is a major burden of mobility for the elderly. The development of arthritis is a multifactorial process. This topic will introduce the basic science and the clinical treatment for the disease.   2.      Osteoporosis   Osteoporosis is one of the most common health problems among the elderly, characterized by low bone mass and deterioration of bone tissues leading to increased bone fragility and fracture risk. In this topic, the causes, preventive measurements and treatments of osteoporosis will be discussed.   3.      Alzheimer’s disease   The molecular basis of interneuron communication (neurotransmission) will be introduced. Clinical signs and problems of the aged brain will be explained. Advances in understanding and treatment of Alzheimer’s disease will be discussed.

title: Fundamentals in Chinese Medicine
requirements: Not for Chinese Medicine Majors.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course introduces the fundamental concepts in Chinese medicine to students who are interested in a general understanding of the basic theories, working principles, methods for health preservation and disease healing in Chinese medicine. The course comprises an introduction to the five key areas in Chinese medicine including the basic theories, methods of diagnosis and treatment, acupuncture & moxibustion, Chinese medicinal materials, and Chinese herbal formulary. This general education module will also include some practical tutorials to demonstrate diagnostic methods, and classic treatments, which include tongue observation, pulse taking, acupuncture and cupping. The medium of instruction for the course is English.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, the student will be able to:     Understand the Chinese philosophy that underpin Chinese medicine practice;    Understand the general properties and processing of Chinese medicinal herbs;    Give an account on the therapeutic properties of some common Chinese herbs;    Discuss the principles of combination of herbal ingredients;    Compare the functions of the visceral organs from the perspectives of Chinese and Western medicine;    Discuss the concepts of channels and acupoints and the principles underpinning acupuncture and moxibustion practice;    Appreciate the principles of Chinese medical diagnostic procedures including four diagnostic techniques and pattern differentiation;    Apply the fundamental knowledge gained in the course for health maintenance and disease prevention.
syllabus: Brief history and characteristics of Chinese medicine    Philosophies of Chinese medicine: the Yin-Yang and Five Elements theories    The internal organs: The five visceral and six bowel organs    The vital substances: Qi, blood and body fluids    The aetiology of disease from Chinese medicine’s perspective    Diagnostics in Chinese medicine    Tutorial in Chinese medical diagnosis    General introduction to acupuncture and moxibustion    Tutorial in acupuncture and moxibustion    Fundamental knowledge of Chinese medicinal herbs               (1) Brief history                 (2) General properties of medicinal herbs              (3) Processing of medicinal herbs              (4) General rules of usage     Medicinal materials in common use    (1) Plant drugs, Animal drugs and Mineral drugs   (2) Therapeutic properties of Chinese medicinal herbs     Herbal formulas    (1) Principles of combination of herbal ingredients   (2) Examples of medicinal formulas      13.   Case studies – application of medicinal herbs in common diseases

title: Science, Philosophy and Human Life
requirements: Not for Philosophy Majors; and students who have taken PHIL4183.;Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: A lively, accessible survey of basic issues in critical thinking and philosophy of science as they bear on daily life and our understanding of the world. The course focuses on three general issues: What is science and how is it different from superstition and pseudoscience? How are theories supported by evidence? and Does science give us the truth about reality? Discussions will address topics such as astrology, fortune-telling, and fengshui; parapsychology, extrasensory perception, and ghosts; creationism vs. evolutionary theory; science, religion, and mystical experience; miracle cures, folk medicine, and medical quackery; relativism and truth; scientific progress, scientific revolutions, and rationality; and whether atoms and black holes really exist.
outcome: Describe the nature of science, scientific explanation, and scientific method.    Understand some of the basic issues in philosophy of science.    Explain how science is different from superstition and pseudoscience.    Apply critical thinking skills to scientific issues in daily life.
syllabus: 1. Understanding Science Inquiry: 1.1 A case: Semmelweis’s work on childbed fever 2. Theories 2.1 Theoretical Models: a. Scale Models: DNA b. Analog Models: Atoms theory c. Theoretical Models: Newtonian mechanics 2.2 Theoretical Hypotheses 2.3 Laws, Theories, and Generalizations: Mendelian Genetics 3. Justifying Scientific Theories 3.1 Testing Newton’s Theory: Halley’s Comet 3.2 What makes a good test? 3.3 Celestial Mechanics and the Phlogiston 4. Fallacies of Theory Testing 4.1 The Delphi Fallacy: Vague Predictions 4.2 The Jeane Dixon Fallacy: Multiple Predictions 4.3 Astrology 4.4 The Patchwork Quilt Fallacy: Conspiracy Theories 4.5 The Ad Hoc Rescue: Failed Predictions 4.6 Justification by Elimination: Extraterrestrial Visitation Revisited 5. Relativism, Truth, and Reality 5.1 Reality is socially constructed: New Agers  5.2 Reality is constituted by conceptual Schemes: Conceptual Relativists 5.3 Facing Reality: Scientific Realism 6. Justifying Statistical Hypotheses 6.1 Estimation: Polling 6.2 Problems with Survey Sampling 6.3 Testing Statistical Hypotheses 7. Justifying Causal Hypotheses 7.1 Saccharin and Cancer 7.2 Causal Hypotheses and Randomized Design 7.3 Effectiveness and Statistical Significance  (Core content: at least 5 of the above topics)
required_readings: 1. Alan F. Chalmers, What is This Thing Called Science? 3rd ed. (Hackett, 2000).    2. title: Exploring the Enigmatic Oceans
requirements: Not for School of Life Sciences Majors and Natural Sciences Major with concentrations in YBSC, YBTC, YENS and YFNC. ;2) Co-requisite: UGFH1000 or UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum).
description: This course aims to provide an overview of the oceans and the roles of natural and anthropogenic impacts on shaping the physical and biological aspects of the oceans. The main themes of the course include the ocean processes, the marine ecosystems and their inhabitants, and the relationships between oceans and mankind. Emphasis will be placed on how natural processes shape the oceans, how the inhabitants survive the marine environment, how we depend on the oceans, the impact of anthropogenic processes on the oceans, and how the future of mankind is affected by the oceans. Examples of topics covered include: the Earth and the oceans, ecosystems of the oceans, marine organisms and their adaptations to the marine environment, exploitation of the oceans, and the management and conservation of the oceans. A laboratory visit to the Simon F.S. Li Marine Science Laboratory will be included to demonstrate the methodology and instruments used in marine research.
outcome: 1.   Recognise the nature and importance of the oceans, and aware that human beings are part of the nature,   2.   Recognise the nature of various marine ecosystems, and compare the characteristics and ecological importance of the individual marine ecosystems;   3.   Identify the factors influencing the various ocean processes, and recognise their interactions and their impact on human life;   4.   Appraise how the balance of the natural environment is maintained and how the oceans as the biggest biome of Earth recycles its living and non-living components through the natural recycling processes;   5.   Recognise the characteristics of various marine organisms, relate their structural or physiological adaptations to the specific marine environments where they survive, and compare ways through which organisms in different marine ecosystems adapt to survive;   6.   Acquire hands-on experience on the theory and application of the common instruments used in marine research through a visit to the Simon F.S. Li Marine Science Laboratory;   7.   Recognise the importance of the oceans as a source of fossil and renewable energy, minerals, food and space for human survival and development;   8.     Explain the harmful effects of marine pollution and over-exploitation of marine resources, and to recognise and affirm the role of humanity in conserving nature in particular the vulnerable marine environment;   9.     Able to collect, analyse, and compile information and data on topics related to the oceans; and construct and submit a project report on the integrated information, as well as delivering the report to the whole class in form of an oral presentation.
syllabus: Theme 1: The Earth, the Oceans & Ocean Processes Contents: (i) overview of the Earth and the major oceans, zonation of the ocean and the respective physical and chemical parameters; (ii) the ocean processes and how their interactions shape global conditions such as climates & weather, and (iii) natural cycling of various elements.   Theme 2: Marine Ecosystems Contents: (i) overview of the characteristics of the marine environment; (ii) coastal ecosystems such as mangroves and coral reefs etc, (iii) pelagic ecosystems such as the open ocean and the deep ocean, and (iv) the hydrothermal vent and cold seep ecosystems.   Theme 3: Marine Organisms A variety of marine organisms will be discussed, in particular (i) the plankton and their importance; (ii) organisms which show specific adaptation to the marine environment; and (iii) whales and dolphins. Emphasis will be placed on the interactions of the organisms with the environment and their survival, and the impact of mankind on the organisms.   Theme 4: Ocean and Man Contents: (i) exploitation and conservation of the resources from the oceans; (ii) fisheries/whaling and aquaculture as means of obtaining food from the sea; (iii) organisms threatened by anthropogenic impact and the concepts of endangered organisms; and (iv) marine pollution and remediation.
